title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2010)
subject: Personal Development

document.title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2010)

83FED4E90F19482DAD69F74D64D9EE1A.description: an argument from authority (e.g. what criteria should we use for making choices when buying sports equipment?)

46EF20F43AB54D27A538B228421C5DD3.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. can you explain to me why boys should not cry?)

6D34314136F14085A88371BB43BE15A5.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. is age linked to a person's abilities?)

CF0A3E84D6544600B460171AB3E00B57.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. is something true simply because a large number of people say it is?)

513BAA462F35481687EFBA18679E1858.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. how does the fact that all your friends can stay out until 9:00 p.m. mean that you can too?)

4C295A53963D4A0DAEF57BD787417B55.description: a personal attack (e.g. do you think you are helping the discussion by calling someone a baby?)

B01EBFA0C0D14C5B86253773E0B27BA6.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. do all cats eat more when they are alone or when they are bored?)

D30F9E1BDBBD4ABDA8ED84B78C2164B6.description: Examines, in a situation involving dialogue:

0AC9F32CFB4245758DFF31B6F1AC2D1C.description: an argument from authority (e.g. we should buy this brand of equipment because our Olympic champion promotes it)

0B0DEE8C3ED54598B2DD006FAC773C7B.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. boys shouldn't cry)

A7F4EA5052BF4F699A1A3915410BB29E.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. my grandmother won't know how to use this electronic device because she is too old)

88F9E792DACC4F848C69EFA0A8E97814.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. my new shoes are certainly the best, because the salesperson told me they are the top sellers)

CCC7696E0F744E07BD3B364F02CAEE52.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. all my friends can stay out until 9:00 p.m., so I can too)

4531A64DEEA64D548E06B07C9CE44352.description: a personal attack (e.g. you're too much of a baby to understand this)

1D2EBCFEF0994EA0B7542A6E721EFAB8.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. when my cat is home alone, he eats more; therefore cats who are bored eat more)

DBE10E4271094A3085D58C706AE22882.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

9948BFB4124044478095ECF2E574E96D.description: an appeal to the crowd (bandwagon), an appeal to prejudice, an appeal to stereotype, an argument from authority

BB742494C7E04CE68C028A3F3B8AEC6B.description: a hasty generalization, a personal attack

AAFF2740B15549DB8C6020718095D5A2.description: a judgment of value (e.g. why do some people say that money leads to happiness?)

B462E003E4054E4BB83583B25F980868.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. can you explain how the date for the Easter celebration is decided?)

C920185B749044AF9FE0B8894CD8BFD6.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. why does this regulation exist?)

47B51B805C0F4B539C5C80F644521989.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. can you explain why you prefer winter?)

4D9DFC0C6C1D43C0A17055B4CBF4C570.description: Examines, in a situation involving dialogue:

F2C55760A1DE4250A9C4D6C81085BEC8.description: a judgment of value (e.g. money creates happiness)

95E5346A49144473933E2434A2A33B7C.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. the Easter celebration takes place in spring, but not on a set date)

0E0601514E244BC2B4E7B8857614B8E5.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. the regulation prohibits running around the swimming pool)

7762B4DF586848CF9EE38DE2B06E0F9D.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. winter is my favourite season; it's the most beautiful season)

7CDCC9FFEAAA4F9CA142646775F08BED.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

0AD5B9E2495D4BC097C64F9CF98FE1B1.description: a judgment of preference, a judgment of prescription

7329B2455DD94858BA925DBD6EC76B1D.description: Explains, in his/her own words the meaning of:

4ADD1208813F4DC59E3BAE76BD72BD8D.description: Means for examining a point of view

AC1C4084EA284F78A9D9288977779E63.description: Uses justification to present, in a logical way, a few reasons and ideas that support a point of view (e.g. presents some reasons that motivate a believer to observe a dietary rule)

2890DF7452B345188F8EB5CB6DFDE63A.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what a justification is (e.g. making a justification means giving several reasons to demonstrate a point of view)

D0D5142CC8B244CABB23F82234323555.description: Uses explanation to help others to know or understand the meaning of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle Two, explains the negative effects of intimidation by referring to what a community police officer said; in Cycle Three, explains the connections between rights and responsibilities by referring to charters, city regulations and the school code)

3116C3ECBE0B470C8D61898A6563EF9C.description: Describes, in his/her own words, what an explanation is (e.g. explaining means providing accurate information to account for how I understand something)

82CFBA712C80456E99F0CF4CBB0F2980.description: Uses synthesis to provide a coherent summary of the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle Two, summarizes his/her discoveries about different ways of celebrating civil marriage or religious marriage; in Cycle Three, summarizes his/her understanding of the founding events of a religious tradition)

E36D9780D87B49CF8666415CDC8EDE83.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what synthesis is (e.g. making a synthesis means summarizing what has been discussed)

169DB27891BC403EBC48B116BFA52449.description: Uses comparison to highlight similarities and differences among the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, names two differences between the needs of animals and those of a human being; in Cycle Two, compares an advantage and a disadvantage of playing alone and in a group; in Cycle Three, compares how children's rights are observed in various areas of the world)

D730F8E7325B4B64B498928C9B747939.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what comparison is (e.g. drawing a comparison means finding differences and similarities between two things)

CC26B79843A94AFBA1BBA481DC4C74D7.description: Uses description to enumerate the characteristics of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, words, objects or gestures for a ritual associated with birth; in Cycle Two, various parts of a place of worship and objects, furnishings and symbols; in Cycle Three, origin, division of time, main markers of time for a calendar)

61C9AE2BD76C4A5CAAE89BD7A9B714A7.description: Explains, in his/her own words, what description is (e.g. giving a description means giving several characteristics of something)

0B5714993B304D7483A3A199B3398AC4.description: Means for developing a point of view

0FCF0777B653496BAC6F535F93985F7A.description: all other paths for fostering dialogue

43F4506B68384B9488C1C851A1C86B34.description: is open to different ways of thinking

3CEEC1A55BB740FDA8612C7FB88B2532.description: introduces nuances to his/her comments and recognizes the nuances introduced by others

86B22D9E88E746B791A040924EFB6812.description: suggests rules for engaging in dialogue

F16ADA31D7A14C7B9A147BEC7510391E.description: Contributes to establishing conditions that foster dialogue

C2C9F8E0255742E1A486CFCCB9F4D319.description: all other paths for fostering dialogue

285F3F8D75834F90995E1E37D27C1A4B.description: attentively listens to what another person has to say in order to grasp the meaning

3E77F9F1771E4E829EFB898BDF4AA3B0.description: respects the right of others to speak

EAA4157DA3E64F32B1B0C8E62E204A84.description: observes rules for engaging in dialogue

2D80A92C584044608C02D39FD74F6024.description: Uses, in a situation involving dialogue:

C0F5BFB5F7EC453883402955C5150268.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the meaning of:

57B9A34998CB4F2CA999C080FE3C45C7.description: Knowledge related to the practice of dialogue

DE518E847F67481FBCC887E183ED9B89.description: Explains the meaning of certain practices related to clothing: origin, reasons and values as the motivation for following these practices, meaning attached to the practice, symbolism, etc.

49F36507E677409795D4F50588182327.description: Describes practices related to clothing based on religious values or norms: obligation or prohibition concerning the form of clothing, its colour, use, etc.

D5F16CD4DFB74B9FA04397030590051F.description: Explains the meaning of certain dietary practices: origin, reasons and values underlying these practices, meaning given to the practice, symbolism, etc.

495532A15A9642969D0A31421F2E696C.description: Describes dietary practices based on religious values or norms: food preparation, meal times, authorized and forbidden food, etc

683D85182F32433CBF230681A3372CE4.description: Explains how the work of an exemplary individual is inspired by values and beliefs (e.g. Le bon Dieu dans la Rue, founded by Father Emmett Johns, known as “Pops,” helps homeless young people; this work is based on the values of charity and sharing, important to the founder)

E53170BAD4F043DD94657B1A8ABF5501.description: Makes connections between religious values or norms and the behaviour or attitudes of certain believers (e.g. in several religious traditions, the value of sharing encourages believers to engage in charity; in Native spirituality, the value of respect for nature means only killing animals for food)

99A4931E48BC4207894E2F518D5B8079.description: Names the values and norms related to various religious traditions (e.g. the Golden Rule for many religious traditions; the Ten Commandments for Christianity and Judaism; respect for nature for Native spirituality; compassion for Buddhism)

338D8DDB567B44EAA69C9345438F5C62.description: Describes various representations or concepts of time (e.g. the origin of the Julian calendar: the number and names of the months, the beginning and duration of the year; linear and cyclical concepts of time)

8828774B769C44B4BF7E00C35FE55157.description: Explains the meaning of forms of religious expression associated with the founders of religious traditions present in Québec (e.g. for Christians, the crucifix recalls the resurrection of Jesus and his mission to save human beings; for Buddhists, Vaisakha recalls the birth and enlightenment of Buddha)

BB0770188E844D5CB4D25D5302E5E078.description: Names forms of religious expression associated with the founders of religious traditions present in Québec (e.g. the crucifix and Jesus; Passover and Moses)

E1E87385A69E42D79C2CC9E78E5EF9C1.description: Relates events to the origins of religious traditions present in Québec (e.g. the death and resurrection of Christ; the Protestant Reformation; Moses receiving the Ten Commandments; the departure of Muhammad for Medina)

7A147CE5EFDD4D3FA5F6780AA6717762.description: Names the place of origin of the religions practised in Québec (e.g. the Mediterranean Basin for Christianity, Judaism and Islam; the Americas for Native spirituality; Europe for Protestantism; India for Buddhism and Hinduism)

A4EA10245AD6434DB8A9D6F20AF18F39.description: Identifies the population distribution of different belief groups (e.g. in the world, there are nearly 1.13 billion Catholics, 800 million Protestants, 14 million Jews, 1.57 billion Muslims) 2.

07B6EFA3DEE84F6BBEEF6F26F6C35D3C.description: Identifies the geographic distribution of the main religious traditions in the world (e.g. making a geographical map showing the distribution of religions; identifying mainly Catholic, Protestant, Muslim countries)

6BA58C365658473DB9257E509B7C372B.description: Religions in society and the world

EE2F63700A9247A89DF4C2136F490B7E.description: Associates forms of religious expression with their religious tradition (e.g. the wayside cross and Christianity; a tombstone bearing the Star of David and Judaism; the peace-pipe and Native spirituality)

A57FFFF6E0104859A0C497C41219CFA7.description: Associates symbols and images with various representations of the world's origins (e.g. representations of earthly paradise, the turtle representing Mother Earth)

079AB07CAAD144C1948E9F5A98BE4649.description: Describes community or cultural works influenced by religion: characteristics, mission, impact in the community, etc.

EA24C9B8091F46378CB11C0AEAA14B08.description: Names community or cultural works influenced by religion (e.g. stained glass, paintings, sculptures as works of art; Saint Vincent de Paul Society as community work; media holiday food drive as a cultural event)

994A05E0EB634518BAEDE8A10D78501B.description: Describes forms of religious expression observed in the environment: what it is, what it represents, its use, appearance, origin, etc

EBADEDED1B32414A93E787F32811B92C.description: Names elements of religious heritage present in the environment (e.g. church bell, cemetery, names of certain streets)

167CD0D78F5644189E2CDAE609D25F28.description: Forms of religious expression in the young person's environment5

7C2E9D50544A425D93FE680D1FAD782D.description: Associates elements of a celebration experienced in a community with the appropriate religious tradition (e.g. the chalice and Christianity; Book of the Word and Protestantism; the tam-tam and Native spirituality; the three crows and Buddhism; the Vedas and Hinduism)

22114A1C7A1148D0ABBA4AA9D475E91E.description: Describes practices of prayer and meditation: places, words recited, gestures, songs, objects used

B77634FD47724F9DB7FE3E57600CD3BF.description: Associates words and writings with their religious tradition (e.g. the Bible and Christianity; the Torah and Judaism; Jesus for Christianity; the Great Spirit and Native spirituality; Allah for Islam)

E701FA46C1E24B03AA637122E61FA62F.description: Associates spiritual guides with one or more religious practices (e.g. the priest and the celebration of the Eucharist; the pastor and the assembly of prayer; the rabbi and the Sabbath prayers; the shaman and Native spirituality)

19D1712E1BAF491BBBD2305EFC3415F1.description: Describes religious celebrations experienced in the community: reasons for the celebration, gestures, words recited, objects used, etc.

4ED96A68E1D84164A34818A13DC65196.description: Describes places of worship, objects or symbols connected with one or more religious practices (e.g. form, furnishings, decorations in the place of worship; form, colour, use of objects; form, origin, meaning of the symbols)

56A461122ECF4AA9B3A82B5709047F6D.description: Names daily, weekly, annual or occasional religious celebrations (e.g. daily prayer, Sunday mass, Seder meal, marriage, funeral)

AEA3EFA4F2604EAA9AAA2550E7F89342.description: Associates stories with their religious tradition (e.g. the Nativity story and Christianity; the story of Glouskap and the story of Beaver who steals fire and Native spirituality; the birth of Gautama and Buddhism)

FAC27EB4228F46B59F513B087EC25DC9.description: Names the important aspects of a story associated with a celebration or an key figure (e.g. the building of Noah’s ark, the animals, the rain, the dove, the rainbow in the story of Noah and the Flood)

555558E45346472FAC8054BB4F10DD74.description: Associates stories with celebrations or key figures (e.g. the story of the Three Wise Men and the celebration of the Epiphany, the Exodus of the Jews from Egypt and the celebration of Succoth)

E40A2B2F41044965934638EC6F8E0FE7.description: Describes forms of religious expression associated with various stories: main aspects, form, colour, location where they take place, use, etc

656DCF864FB541BC9ECC712787F9DBAF.description: Names forms of religious expression that are associated with various stories (e.g. the nativity scene, the galette des rois and the story of Jesus' birth, Native masks and stories)

0B1C8AE7706E476CBA8A5F7D1A92024D.description: Associates rituals associated with birth with their tradition of origin (e.g. baptism and Christianity; whispering the call to prayer and Islam)

4DA3EB5630964A94AB56AC89EBB861D3.description: Associates celebrations with their tradition of origin (e.g. Christmas and Christianity, Passover and Judaism, powwow and Native traditions, the secular celebration of Mother's Day)

D18E2D19DCBE4DF2AA37C9ACDB08C5C7.description: Describes rituals associated with birth: locations for the rituals, gestures, words, people present, etc

1B4087C93206461CA4244E2B9C016357.description: Names rituals associated with birth2 (e.g. baptism, walking out ceremony, planting a tree)

00E268DCE95643A48FFE5C1F58EC17D4.description: Describes ways of experiencing family celebrations: how the celebration is held, special decorations, special menu, guests, etc.

3463AEB163F843239176A4538522BA37.description: Names celebrations (e.g. Easter, Hanukkah, Mother's Day, Diwali, birthdays)

93F0AA7F4C80444B99BF9CEF47DA02AE.description: Knowledge related to themes of religious culture

694A6A6921D14EA08AE1A3D960C808AD.description: Formulates ethical questions (e.g. what is a just society, what does "being equal" mean?)

96C9971AC64441948FF45ABB4FAA68E3.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, spiritual leaders, media)

1C7DD9A732844B60990F68FB0E8477CB.description: Learning common to all themes at the elementary level

A54E92DDDD97492F9A8846675B98632A.description: Names the possible connections between a right and a responsibility (e.g. the right to borrow a book at the library and the responsibility for taking care of it; the right to use a municipal park and the responsibility for behaving like a good citizen)

44444D27E0B945FA802521511902231B.description: Explains how values or norms guide life in society (e.g. the value "saving the environment" encourages reduced consumption of drinking water; the classification system for video games guides parents and children in their choices)

CC720E83C83B4B71A9A1393F39E16010.description: Explains how actions and attitudes can reduce tensions or conflicts in society (e.g. tensions between motorists and cyclists can be reduced if everyone abides by road safety rules and signals their intentions)

BFD88F860979493CAD735F900AF16ECF.description: Names sources of tension or conflict in society (e.g. discrimination, different interpretations of a rule, social inequalities)

5C34E4C14DA941EEA6EC9751CB9C8D55.description: Explains how actions and attitudes can detract from life in society (e.g. vandalism gives rise to costs that all citizens have to pay

8C96A751825C43B99F33204775CBCEFE.description: Explains how actions or attitudes can foster life in society (e.g. denouncing an individual caught in the act of theft contributes to neighbourhood safety)

23529C2E01F04BE5B95847E0BF32BE53.description: Indicates what distinguishes an acceptable action from an unacceptable action (e.g. does an action result in prejudice, harm, discomfort or injustice?)

A84D1BC1E5654DDBB8ADB48F1B95EA98.description: Names the possible effects of prejudices, generalizations and stereotypes (e.g. there could be discrimination, rejection, injustice, categorization)

93D493AF6D124927999CD5664EC070A6.description: Gives examples of prejudices, generalizations or stereotypes that are present in society (Prejudice: he is certainly the one who did it because he is the leader of his group; Generalization: my neighbour likes hunting, therefore all men like this activity; Stereotype: children who come from this neighbourhood are more intelligent than children from other neighbourhoods)

9F799B74E3CD4650826DE2ACD63AC0E1.description: Explains how the differences among individuals can be a source of conflict (e.g. the competitive spirit can create conflict with those who only value participation; when people do not speak the same language, they may not always understand each other very well)

D281DF1F04DD436EAFD81F8419E4B9DE.description: Explains how differences among individuals can be a source of enrichment (e.g. writing to a pen pal in another country can lead to enriching discoveries: music, recipes, values, ways of life)

8D06A9715DE8406DBC2F0A6CAF8E455F.description: Gives examples of situations in which the influence of members of a society has an impact on self-assertiveness (e.g. a student refuses or decides to wear an article of clothing widely advertised in the media and worn by many friends)

73143AC373F541EB9FA973629BD348F5.description: Explains how members of a society influence each other (e.g. more and more people use reusable grocery bags, which creates a ripple effect)

85AAFCDA7D8A4C519581B4F499A5A37B.description: Names the conditions that foster the personal well-being of the members of a group (e.g. sharing material in the classroom, establishing a conflict-management procedure)

2B7C70E1D5554519B668838A878ACF79.description: Names the roles and responsibilities that members of a group may assume (e.g. in a drama group, all actors have to memorize their parts)

E3BBA822FB3B4F268A3AA5B46AB5A65A.description: Gives examples of situations in which values or norms can be questioned, modified or improved to foster community life (e.g. although keeping a secret is usually a good idea, sometimes, to help a friend, a secret should be revealed to an adult)

0FA344F7407A4714A40FCBA517468150.description: Explains how norms guide group life (e.g. in karate classes, the teacher asks everyone to change teammates on a regular basis to avoid creating subgroups)

608342313CBF4DC78A254A958E108B2F.description: Explains how values guide group life (e.g. the value of respect encourages students to wait their turn to speak and allows everyone to express an opinion without being interrupted)

B19B0B58BDA2494A996BC6AFA7B2D9BA.description: Explains how behaviours, attitudes or actions can detract from group life (e.g. insulting a friend, or talking behind his/her back creates tension in the group and can cause conflicts)

18720B79142F479585E2D2CED7437680.description: Explains how behaviours, attitudes or actions can foster group life (e.g. by adopting a calm attitude in class, everyone contributes to creating a pleasant atmosphere conducive to work, and the whole group benefits)

E68211AC27FA49AD9814A757079E62F7.description: Demands of belonging to a group

6E0E80D9250B40B6BEFDA712FE01971C.description: Explains how interpersonal relationships can contribute to or detract from the personal development of group members (e.g. when the captain of a team encourages the players, the players feel appreciated and this reinforces their self-esteem; a player who feels rejected by the members of his/her team loses self-confidence)

1ED24E77D6784808B2FEEA7F882805A1.description: Names various types of relationships that can exist among the members of a group (e.g. friendship, leadership and conflictual relationships can exist among classmates)

3DEB7206943346BB9E0FE255A5CA726E.description: Gives examples of situations illustrating the disadvantages of group life (e.g. since many students want to play on the play structure, they all have to be patient and wait their turn, make compromises and learn to share the space)

52D2EA5A0B09466583324C2691C80181.description: Gives examples of situations illustrating the advantages of group life (e.g. through the cooperation and solidarity of all students in the school, the school yard cleanup was done quickly and everyone had more time to play)

AEC7EFDCB4CE4D0CADA04D3D7F2CCB88.description: Gives examples of situations where needs are met in a group (e.g. by celebrating my birthday, my friends and my family meet my need to be loved and be recognized)

65E99B0679B84351A93A8E4E279DB8FC.description: Makes connections between belonging to a group or groups and the development of personal identity (e.g. influence of a group of friends on musical tastes, influence of family on recreational activities, belonging to a scout troop and the ability to survive in a forest)

18C99CCB1B594C22BCE68B3FC60FA6D3.description: Names the groups to which people belong4 (e.g. family, class, friends, sports team, drama group, choir)

FD9C7B9F08594C22B2E93C91A0A294D7.description: Names people or groups who take action to protect living beings (e.g. police officers, school crossing guards, Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals)

5656F63D383D4368AF2C027BCC5FBEDC.description: Gives examples of actions that can harm living beings (e.g. saying hurtful things, hitting an animal, ripping a plant out of the soil)

2D60A2A6F77A4050A7B29394DB481C77.description: Gives examples of actions that may foster the well-being of living beings (e.g. consoling a friend, sharing toys, feeding a pet)

ABE2128A413D4B6889C57A775DFCEF43.description: Names the norms that guide behaviour in families and at school (e.g. bedtime, rules of conduct in class)

71935A9F5887467C9D076FACF6C99B15.description: Names the values that guide behaviour in families and at school (e.g. sharing, attention to others, safety, respect)

BAE67315445D4233993BCBDEF28C627F.description: Names the responsibilities that different people at school may assume (e.g. a student is responsible for cleaning the board; the principal organizes parent-teacher meetings; the secretary records absences)

8C9D63FD1E9849409085B173D2E279A2.description: Names the responsibilities that different family members may assume (e.g. parents are responsible for feeding their children; a child might be responsible for walking the dog)

3B21173211714E09871C03789DB772CB.description: Demands associated with the interdependence of humans and other living beings

BF8DE01D89664EE09A265B7FE4A86969.description: Gives examples of actions illustrating that the members of a family need each other (e.g. children need parents to give them shelter; parents need their children to cooperate to create a pleasant living environment)

02CB39B4B9364B16B548D432927139EA.description: Gives examples of actions illustrating that living beings need each other (e.g. the farmer grows the vegetables I eat)

E086889C22B94F8685C8BDE14973BC9B.description: Names the needs that are not shared by plants, animals and human beings (e.g. human being's need for clothing, in contrast to animals and plants)

8F754EEBAB444BED9C8979BE0E9565A4.description: Names the needs shared by plants, animals and human beings (e.g. need for food)

26D7ABB8D3C749A285F5C0ACD60BA9FD.description: Names the elements that contribute to the unique character of each human being (e.g. personal history, preferences, talents, physical characteristics)

37DC1F820079467B8C2F2203B6EB9A5A.description: The needs of humans and other living beings
